0.text:
Greetings Gastronauts! This is Keef Cooks,
I'm Keef and today I'm going to show you how

5.text:
I made a rather special birthday cake for
two people.

15.text: So the first person this is for has just had her 90th birthday - sadly, she won't be getting any of this cake,

22.text: but it's the thought that counts. Our monarch, Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, by the Grace of God,

28.text: of Great Britain, Ireland, and British Dominions Beyond the Seas, Queen, and Defender of the Faith.

35.text: And about a million other things.

37.text: And the second person this is for is another Queen. The Queen of Romantic Lady Novelists,

42.text:
our friend Kate, who's just had her hmmph-hmpph
birthday.

45.text:
So I was inspired to make this cake a few
weeks ago when I read that last year's Great

49.text:
British Bake-Off winner, Nadiya Hussain, had
been commissioned to make a cake for the Queen's

54.text:
90th Birthday. Which is brilliant, absolutely
brilliant news. And I though, hmm, I wonder

61.text:
what she'll make? Anyway, I found out later,
she made a Lemon Drizzle Cake. Here's a picture.

66.text:
It's a bit wonky, but you haven't seen mine
yet.

70.text:
Because, I thought, if it was me, I would
make a cake in the shape of the Imperial State Crown.

77.text: And I did. Or I tried to. It's very difficult, don't try this at home, unless you're completely insane.

86.text:
So I decided that the best kind of cake would
be a fruit cake - not a sponge 'cos that's

91.text:
probably not dense enough to take the icing.
So it'll be rich and fruity, but not solid

96.text: enough to build houses out of.

97.text: I'm going to make 3 different cakes, different sizes. So I've got 3 tins - a small one, a medium-size one, a big one.

107.text: I won't bother telling you what sizes these are, 'cos I know you're never going to make this.

111.text: So, ingredients, I've got 450g each of self-raising flour, butter, and caster sugar. Powdered sugar.

119.text:
I've also got 100g of ground almonds,
a teaspoon of almond extract, 8 eggs, a teaspoon

127.text:
of mace, and 900g of dried fruit. Now the
dried fruit needs to be macerated in a liquid

135.text:
so it plumps up a bit. And the best liquid
would be a load of brandy. But I haven't got

141.text:
any, so orange juice is fine. And ideally
you should leave that overnight.

146.text:
OK, let's start making the cake batter. First
thing we need to do is cream together the

154.text:
butter and the sugar. And this is probably
the hardest part of making cakes. It's a bit

159.text:
laborious. You want your butter cut into small
chunks, and soft, so that you can just kind

167.text: of melt it, mix it into the sugar.

173.text:
So for the first few minutes of doing this,
you'll probably think this is never going

176.text:
to work, but keep at it. It does work eventually.
So the next stage is to add the eggs, one

185.text:
at a time, beat them in. And when that's beaten
in you can add the next one. Not before!

192.text:
And I'm actually going to stop there, I've
got 6 eggs in, and that's looking a bit sloppy.

197.text:
I think that might be enough eggs. So the
next job is to fold in the flour, and the

202.text: ground almonds. And the almond extract.

205.text:
Right, now it's time to put the fruit in,
and if you like you can add candied peel,

212.text:
glace cherries or whatever you like really.
What you need to do now is preheat your oven

218.text:
to 160 degrees Celcius, and butter your tins
generously. Some people like to line their

225.text:
tins with greaseproof paper - I'm not one
of them 'cos that's just a bit too much work.

231.text: Now we fill each tin with batter.

233.text:
There ya go, I've left a space in the top
of each one - I think these probably will

238.text:
rise a bit because we've got lots of eggs
and self-raising flour in there. And these

243.text:
need to go in the oven for at least an hour
- obviously they're different sizes, so they'll

247.text: take different amounts of time to cook.

249.text:
And we have a bowl full of yummy stuff. And
I don't know what the protocol nowadays is,

254.text:
what with raw eggs being poisonous, but when
I was kid we used to fight over this,

259.text: licking out the bowl was the best thing.

262.text:
OK, this little one's had 55 minutes, and
I'm going to stick a skewer in the middle,

269.text:
and if it comes out dry, which it does, that's
done. Oh yeah, lovely, that's done as well. The big

275.text:
one, I think, will take another 10 or 15 minutes.
So when the cakes have cooled down a little

279.text:
bit, til they're cool enough to handle, just
get them out of the tins, put them on a wire

286.text:
So, in case the Imperial State Crown doesn't
mean anything to you, it was made for the

291.text:
Coronation of George the Sixth in 1937, and
closely modelled on one that had been made

297.text:
for the Coronation of Queen Victoria about
a century previously. And Queen Elizabeth

303.text: wore it for her Coronation and they bring it out of the shed every year for the State Opening of Parliament.

309.text:
So really it's quite an astounding thing.
It contains 3 of the world's biggest gems,

314.text:
over 2,800 diamonds, hundreds of pearls, rubies,
emeralds, you name it, it's got it. It's bling

323.text:
upon bling upon bling. And what it says to
visiting foreign potentates is

328.text: 'Listen Matey, I've got more wealth on my head than you've got in your entire country. So just behave.'

334.text:
Right, here's our mountain of cake, and I
have to tell you there's been a bit of nibbling

338.text:
going on, and it's absolutely delicious. So
what I need to do is level off the tops of

343.text:
the individual cakes, stick them together
with buttercream icing, and sculpt it into

350.text:
the curvy shape of the velvet inside the crown,
and ice it again all over with buttercream.

359.text:
And then stick it in the fridge. So, that's
going to be exciting, let's get going.

363.text:
Ingredients for the buttercream icing, I've
got 500g of icing sugar - confectioner's sugar,

369.text:
250g of butter, cut into small chunks. And
4 tablespoons of milk with some saffron infusing

377.text:
in it, and this is to give it a nice golden
colour and a rich and royal flavour.

384.text:
So, first thing to do is cream the butter,
which just means work it with a fork to get

390.text:
it nice and soft. You need to start with fairly
warm softened butter. OK, that's kind of how

398.text:
it should be and I'm now going to add half
of the icing sugar and work that in. Now I'm

404.text:
going to add a bit of the milk and work that
in as well just to loosen the mixture because

410.text:
it's gone pretty stiff. Put the rest of the
sugar in, [ SIGHS ]  and incorporate that.

419.text:
OK, so that's everything in, we'll set this
on one side and start carving the cake. So

425.text:
I've just shaved a few lumps off the top of
this. That's more or less flat enough, so

432.text:
I'm going to spread it with a good layer of
buttercream, and this will be the glue for

436.text:
the layers of cake, basically. And the second
one, I've just broken it. That's possibly

444.text:
a problem, but we'll see if we can glue it
back together. This never happens on the Bake-Off.

448.text:
It looks a bit of a mess right now, but believe
me when it's finished, it'll be fabulous.

454.text:
So now we'll put the top cake on, and this
is going to need some serious sculpting to

459.text:
get the kind of rounded, curving, dimpled
shape. Does that look like a crown to you?

467.text:
So now we'll just coat the top and most of
the sides, not all the way down to the bottom,

472.text:
with the buttercream. Here it is, looking
pretty sloppy at the moment. So I'm going

478.text:
to slap that in the fridge for an hour for
the buttercream to firm up, and during that

482.text: time I'll sort out some fondant icing.

485.text:
Right, now I'm going to cover the top part
of the crown with purple fondant icing. And

492.text:
I have to admit, at this point I'm in completely
uncharted territory - I've never done anything

497.text:
like this before. So, first thing you need
to do is, with a bit of string, measure what

505.text: will be the diameter of the fondant icing.

508.text:
So I've got 2 500g packs of ready-to-roll
fondant icing. I suspect I'm just going to

515.text:
need one and a half, I've got some cling film,
plastic film, because you need to keep your

521.text:
icing covered at all times when you're not
using it because otherwise it dries out really

525.text:
quickly. And I've also got some massively
overpriced gel food colouring, Ultra Violet.

532.text:
I've got a fallback plan because I don't think
that's going to give me a deep enough shade

536.text:
to colour the whole lot of that. I've also
got some cornflour to sprinkle on the surface

542.text:
and stop it sticking. And a good old rolling
pin.

546.text:
So we need to start off kneading the fondant
to get it soft. And if it's really too hard

552.text:
to work with you can microwave it for about
10 seconds to soften it. So I've added some

558.text:
food colouring goop. Aargh I'm going to get
purple fingers from this. See! And here's a

566.text:
tip I've just made up, it gets very sticky,
so I reckon keeping a bowl of water handy

572.text:
So, as I suspected, this teeny tube of colouring
gel, which cost £1 by the way, has had almost

583.text:
no impact on the icing, so I'm going to use
a little bit of blue colouring powder, and

589.text:
some red. These industrial-strength things
probably cost a pound as well - much better

595.text:
value! Just dissolve that in a little bit
of water, and then we'll add that to the fondant.

602.text:
And mix that in, that's more like it. [SQUELCH! ] 
It's like being at primary school this,

610.text:
great fun! Lots of mess. Looks like something
from another planet. I'm going to stick that

618.text:
in a plastic bag because I think that probably
needs to rest, and even if it doesn't, I do.

624.text:
Right, I've rolled out the fondant, and it's
just a bit bigger than my bit of string all

629.text:
the way round. And it looks a bit streaky,
but I'll pretend that's deliberate. So now

636.text:
the next bit, the next challenge is to get
it on the cake [ MOAN, GROAN ] Oh no, it's tearing.

642.text:
I'm going to try rolling it out onto a bit
of greaseproof paper. OK, here's the cake,

664.text:
OK, that was exciting,
so I guess I lost a bit there. I'll see if

671.text:
I can stick it. And I didn't get it centred,
so I've got quite a bit of excess down here

677.text:
- this tin is my measure, by the way. Excess
is good, 'cos we've got the opposite of excess

684.text:
round the other side. I'm sure any fondant
cake decorators out there will be laughing

691.text: their socks off at this, but I don't care.

694.text:
Right, the professionals have little nylon
things for doing this job, but I don't. But

702.text:
I don't actually want a perfectly smooth finish,
I want it to be a little bit kind of stippled,

708.text:
like velvet, so I'm going to dab it all over
with cheesecloth. And now I think that needs

713.text:
to rest for a few hours, so I'll stick it
in a plastic bag and pop it in, well, a cool

721.text:
Right, so here's the slightly weird-looking
cake from yesterday. Now I'm going to do a

726.text:
band of black coloured marzipan around the
bottom. I've got some black food colouring,

732.text:
but that's not obviously going to be anything
like enough. So I'm going to mix red, blue

737.text:
and green colouring powder and try and get
that into the marzipan and hope that works.

743.text:
This is a quarter of a teaspoon, so, an eighth
of a teaspoon of each colour, and I'll just

750.text:
add a few drops of water to that. Try and
work that into the marzipan. I did intend

756.text:
to get some latex gloves when I went shopping
this morning, but I forgot, so it's going

761.text: to be black fingernails all day long. Again.

764.text:
So I'm just going to measure the diameter
of the cake with a bit of string, and the

770.text:
height - which will be the width of the strip
I'm going to roll - is, 4 centimetres, that's

777.text:
an inch and a half. So we want a load of cornflour
to stop it sticking, and we just roll away.

783.text:
You can hardly see this against the black
worktop, but that's a strip of marzipan, and

792.text:
it needs to be quite thick, it's got to be
thicker than the actual icing on the cake.

798.text:
And I've got some cold water, I'm just going
to moisten the marzipan, which will make it

804.text:
stick, I hope. And then I'll place it on to
the cake. It's moments like this when you

810.text:
might wish you had a cake turntable, but I
don't. I'm just going to try and wash off the cornflour.

816.text:
So, this isn't turning out to be the perfectly
accurate representation of the crown that

822.text:
I was hoping for, so we're going for a cartoon
crown look instead, and we'll try not to obsess

828.text:
about little details. Because also I need
to get this done in the next few days, and

836.text:
I've got these silver balls, they're actually,
you know cake decorations sometimes they're really teeth-breakers,

842.text:
but these are cute, they're like puffed wheat
or something. They're really soft when you crunch into them

848.text:
So I was going along, merrily thinking about
making this cake sometime this year, when,

853.text:
about a week ago, a meet up was arranged with
our friend Kate and her lovely husband, in

859.text:
Haworth, West Yorkshire, not very far from
here, which is the home of the Brontes. And

865.text: those two being writers they're very interested in that. So, we were looking forward to it.

871.text: And it turned out this was maybe not the best day to visit Haworth because they were having

876.text: a 1940s weekend and people were dressed up and there was lots of World War 2 memorabilia

883.text: kicking about, Jeeps and things, and a fly-past by a Spitfire which was amazing.

887.text: And also, in an antique shop, a replica of the Imperial State Crown.

894.text:
Now, in my cake-obsessed state, I thought,
flippin' 'eck, somebody's nicked my idea,

901.text:
they've made a cake in the shape of the Imperial
State Crown. Anyway, it turned out not to

905.text:
be, it was a copy of the real thing, and it
was amazing, it's astounding! I'd only seen

911.text:
rubbish photos from the Interwebz, and if
I'd actually seen the replica, I would never

917.text:
ever have attempted to try to make it as a
cake, because waaaah.

922.text:
Now I'm going to start making these bands
that criss-cross the top of it, and I had

927.text:
wanted them to stand proud of the actual cake,
but I don't think that's going to be possible.

933.text:
And what you can't really see clearly on this
photo is that the elements are actually oak

940.text:
leaves, or in the shape of oak leaves. So
what I'm going to try and do is make little

944.text:
cut-out oak leaves of marzipan and I'm
going to cover them in royal icing. And then

950.text:
I've got these white shimmer pearls that have
a lovely pearlized finish, although, if you

955.text:
bite into one of these, you can wave your
teeth goodbye. So I'm going to smash these

960.text:
up into tiny little fragments and embed them
in the royal icing. So I'm just going to try

966.text: and see if I can crush them with the rolling pin.

972.text:
I'm going to make the royal icing, so I've
got my ingredients. I've got 3 egg whites,

976.text:
half a kilo of icing sugar - confectioner's
sugar - and 2 or 3 tablespoons of lemon juice.

983.text:
First thing to do is beat the eggs to make
them frothy.

990.text: Looks frothy to me. Now we add

993.text: the icing sugar, a tablespoon at a time.

998.text: Now I want to add in the lemon juice. Crikey, what a useless bottle! Come on [ LAUGHS ].

1007.text:
Stir that in. And then we keep beating this until we get
stiff peaks. OK, I reckon that'll do.

1019.text: So I'll put that in a sealed plastic container until I need it.

1027.text:
This is what I'm doing now - curved top end,
and then a basic kind of leaf outline that

1036.text:
tapers inwards towards the stem. So, a skewer
to wiggle some holes near the edge, and then

1045.text:
we'll just cut upwards. And keep all your
bits of marzipan under cling film to stop

1053.text: them drying out too much while you're working.

1054.text:
And actually, I've just had another brainwave.
I'm going to sprinkle on the glittery stuff,

1061.text:
pearly stuff, before I cut out the leaves,
and then I can actually roll it into the surface

1066.text: properly. And now I'll cut out the leaves again, but I think I'll do them quite a bit smaller this time.

1072.text:
Right now I've got a stack of golden glittery
oak leaves, so let's try with this lot.

1080.text:
And I'm going to work from the top down, so that
they overlap the right way. There we go,

1087.text:
I'm just going to trim off the bottom edge of
this last one, and hope that they don't fall

1095.text:
Right, I've made a couple of things, square
things. There's a name for these but I've

1099.text:
forgotten what it is. So there's one to go
on the top - that's a double-sided one and

1103.text:
it's on a stick 'cos that will go down into
the cake to support it. And this one, which

1109.text:
goes behind the Black Prince's Ruby. So these
are made out of marzipan and they are covered

1116.text: in the smashed up shimmer pearl things.

1119.text:
So I'm just going to tidy those up and then
I've got a secret thing thing. Some silver

1123.text:
spray glitter - I can't believe I bought glitter,
I hate the stuff!

1128.text: It's a bit meagre, the pump-action thing. It might be better to take the lid off and just spoon it on.

1135.text:
So here's the cake with its cross of oak leaves
on it, and I'm just going to pop in some silver

1141.text:
balls to try and make it look like pearls,
ho ho. OK now I'm just going to spray some

1148.text:
glitter on, and I've just got some foil to
try and mask off the purple bit underneath

1153.text:
'cos we don't really want glitter on that.
This could take a while, so go and have a

1158.text: cup of tea, come back later.

1159.text:
Now then, I'm going to need some jewels. Emeralds
green, sapphires blue, red rubies and the

1170.text:
big red ruby, and some clear diamonds. So
I'm cheating a little bit - I've got some

1175.text:
green jelly - Jell-O, which is lime flavoured,
and I've got some red jelly Jell-O, which

1181.text:
is strawberry flavoured. But strangely, you
can't get blue or clear, so I'm going to have to make that up.

1186.text:
So I need some moulds for my jewels, I'm going
to use one of these as a mould for the big

1191.text:
Cullinan II diamond, and then I'll maybe carve
it a little bit after. And I'm going to use

1196.text:
this ice cube tray for the smaller gems. I
know they are actually too big, and the wrong

1201.text:
shape, but they have got squidgy silicone
bottoms, so it'll be easier to get them out,

1205.text:
and I may cut them down to rectangles or squares
later. I dunno.

1210.text:
So I've got some water coming to the boil,
not too much, just what I think will be enough,

1218.text:
and I'm going to add 6 teaspoons of sugar.
Get that dissolved, and a few drops of peppermint

1228.text:
extract, just to give it a bit of flavour.
And I need my jelly to set quite firmly so

1234.text:
I'm using one and a half sachets of gelatine.
Which may be too much, maybe not enough, I

1240.text: don't know. And I've got some warm water, and just sprinkle some in.

1247.text:
And I'll add that to the water, let that simmer
for a bit, until the gelatine is fully dissolved.

1256.text:
And I'll just pop a bit of that into this
mould and stick it in the freezer for a bit

1262.text:
to see how it sets. There it is - Cullinan
II diamond [ LAUGHS ] So I'll just tidy it

1270.text:
up a bit, try and shape it so it looks more
diamondy. OK, I'll pop that onto some royal

1279.text:
Right, so now I know this is a good setting
jelly, I'll just make some more diamonds.

1287.text:
And now to make the sapphires, I'm just going
to add the teeniest teeniest bit of blue food

1293.text:
colouring to the jelly, 'cos you know how
strong this stuff is. That actually looks about right.

1297.text: And we stick that in the freezer to set.

1299.text:
Now, I bet you're all dying to know what my
plan is to make this orb. And so was I till

1307.text:
a few days ago, 'cos I was really struggling
to think what I could do. But anyway, I have

1313.text:
what may be a solution - da-da-daaaa! Tunnock's
Tea Cakes. Now, if you don't know what these

1319.text:
are, they're a total sugar rush, amazing things.
They're little domes of chocolate enclosing

1329.text:
marshmallow, with a sort of little biscuit
at the bottom, all covered in chocolate and

1335.text:
they are absolutely wonderful. And I haven't
had one for centuries! So I got a pack of 6.

1340.text:
There are 2 left. And what I need to do
is carefully cut off the biscuit base.

1347.text: Well, that didn't go according to plan [ LAUGHS ] Ah dear, back to the drawing board. I've

1354.text:
got a tomato there, maybe I could coat it
in icing - nobody'll eat it anyway.

1357.text:
Now I'm going to do the Black Prince's Ruby,
which is this odd-shaped thing here. The reason

1361.text:
it's a funny shape like that is, it was originally
a pendant, and you see that red blob there,

1368.text:
that was the hole for the strap or the chain
or whatever, which has been plugged with another ruby.

1374.text:
This is my ruby, which I actually made from
red jelly in the egg tray from the fridge.

1382.text:
And it's quite nice, but it's the wrong shape
and it's a bit too big, so I'm going to hack

1385.text: it about with a hot knife.

1387.text:
Now I'm going to stick it on the thing whose
name I still can't remember, with a bit of

1394.text:
royal icing. I've just had a brainwave for
the orb! This fella. I can use this, and just

1399.text:
melt some chocolate into those, so it'll be
like a hollow chocolate sphere. And then,

1403.text: it's a bit small so I'll bulk it up with thick icing.

1406.text:
I've got half a bar of cooking chocolate and
I'll just break it into bits and I'm going

1413.text:
to use the microwave melting technique for
this. So what you do is you put it in for

1417.text:
20 seconds, give it a stir, and give it another
20 seconds and stir it again. And keep repeating

1424.text:
that until it's all melted. OK, the chocolate's
all melty-melty, so I'll pop a bit into each

1429.text:
dimple. Quite a lot actually 'cos I want thick
strong walls, like what you don't get on a

1435.text:
Tunnock's Tea Cake. And we just swirl it round
until chocolate has coated the whole indentation.

1444.text:
OK the chocolate has set, and now I need to
get it out of the moulds. So I'm going to

1450.text:
immerse them in hot water. Ooh look! It's
melted. Try again, I'll re-refrigerate that,

1458.text:
and try and get it out using slightly less
hot water. Well, it's kind of worked, but

1463.text:
it's not brilliant. So I persevered a bit
and I stuck two bits onto a stick, and y'know,

1470.text:
that is shocking. I can't put that on a cake.
And it's not hollow any more, it's absolutely

1475.text:
solid chocolate. So, we'll forget about the
orb. I don't know what I'll do instead.

1481.text:
Now I want to decorate this lower frieze with
jewels, and what I found was if - I thought

1489.text:
I could just pop them on with royal icing
and they'd stay where you put them. But because

1493.text:
of gravity they slide down. So what I've got
is a little... well it's actually the lid

1499.text:
from the glitter spray thing. And I can use
this to make an indentation in the icing,

1512.text:
well this is marzipan. I'll just scrape some
of that out, and that'll hold it in place

1521.text:
until the royal icing sets. Bit of icing on
the back of the jewel, stick it in, and that

1527.text: should stay where I put it.

1528.text:
OK, so that was like 5pm on Friday evening,
and we were meeting our mates in Haworth at

1535.text:
11 o'clock the next morning. And this cake
had to be finished one way or another. I had

1541.text:
almost lost the will to live, and then Mrs
KeefCooks came in and said 'cheer up luv'

1548.text:
and suggested that I forget about trying to
make the Imperial State Crown and concentrate

1553.text: on making this into a cake worth having.

1557.text:
So I did, and it turned out actually quite
amazingly well. The cake itself is delicious.

1564.text: The jellies were rubbish, the royal icing didn't set, it was a nightmare, but y'know, a learning experience!

1571.text:
And that's that, I hope you enjoyed it. Now
please share it with all your friends on social

1574.text:
media, subscribe to this channel, follow us
on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and don't

1579.text:
forget the amazing website that has all the
details of all the recipes. And thank you
